147.title: Punishment for rioting
147.legal_text: Whoever is guilty of rioting, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
147.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
147.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
147.practical_explanation: Penalty for participating in a riot.
147.example: Being part of a violent mob.

148.title: Rioting, armed with deadly weapon
148.legal_text: Whoever is guilty of rioting, being armed with a deadly weapon...
148.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both
148.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
148.practical_explanation: Rioting while carrying weapons like knives, swords, or guns.

149.title: Every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object
149.legal_text: If an offence is committed by any member of an unlawful assembly in prosecution of the common object of that assembly, every person who... is a member of the same assembly, is guilty of that offence.
149.nature:
Cognizable (if offence is)
Bailable (if offence is)
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court triable for main offence
149.practical_explanation: Vicarious liability: If one member of the mob kills someone, everyone can be charged with murder.
149.example: Being in a mob where someone shoots a police officer.
149.conclusion: Expands liability to all group members.

160.title: Punishment for committing affray
160.legal_text: Whoever commits an affray, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine, or with both.
160.punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 month, or fine, or both
160.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
160.practical_explanation: Fighting in a public place disturbing peace.
160.example: Two people fighting on a street corner.

182.title: False information, with intent to cause public servant to use his lawful power to the injury of another person
182.legal_text: Whoever gives to any public servant any information which he knows or believes to be false...
182.punishment: Imprisonment up to 6 months, or fine, or both
182.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate
182.practical_explanation: Misleading police or officials to harass someone.
182.example: Filing a false complaint to get police to raid a neighbor.

201.title: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence, or giving false information to screen offender
201.legal_text: Whoever, knowing that an offence has been committed, causes any evidence... to disappear...
201.punishment: Depends on the offence (7 years, 3 years, etc.)
201.nature:
Cognizable (if offence is)
Bailable (generally)
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session or Magistrate
201.practical_explanation: Destroying evidence or lying to protect a criminal.
201.example: Cleaning bloodstains from a crime scene.
next_steps: Do not tamper with crime scenes.

212.title: Harbouring offender
212.legal_text: Whenever an offence has been committed, whoever harbours or conceals a person whom he knows or has reason to believe to be the offender.
212.punishment: Depends on offence (5 years, 3 years, etc.)
212.nature:
Cognizable (if offence is)
Bailable (generally)
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
212.practical_explanation: Hiding a criminal from the police.
212.example: Letting a fugitive stay in your house.

268.title: Public nuisance
268.legal_text: A person is guilty of a public nuisance who does any act or is guilty of an illegal omission which causes any common injury, danger or annoyance to the public...
268.nature:
Definition (Punished under 290)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
268.practical_explanation: Doing something that annoys or endangers the general public.
268.example: Blocking a public road with construction material.

269.title: Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life
269.legal_text: Whoever unlawfully or negligently does any act which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe to be, likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life.
269.punishment: Imprisonment up to 6 months, or fine, or both
269.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
269.practical_explanation: Carelessness that could spread a deadly disease.
269.example: Breaking quarantine while infected with COVID-19.

294.title: Obscene acts and songs
294.legal_text: Whoever, to the annoyance of others, does any obscene act in any public place, or sings, recites or utters any obscene song...
294.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine, or both
294.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
294.practical_explanation: Doing or saying dirty things in public.
294.example: Singing lewd songs near a school.

319.title: Hurt
319.legal_text: Whoever causes bodily pain, disease or infirmity to any person is said to cause hurt.
319.nature:
Definition (Punished under 323)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate

320.title: Grievous hurt
320.legal_text: Designates 8 kinds of hurt as grievous: Emasculation, loss of sight/hearing, loss of limb, fracture, dangerous hurt.
320.nature:
Definition (Punished under 325)
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Any Magistrate
320.practical_explanation: Severe injuries like broken bones, permanent damage.

332.title: Voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from his duty
332.legal_text: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt to any person being a public servant in the discharge of his duty...
332.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both
332.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
332.practical_explanation: Hitting a police officer or official who is working.

339.title: Wrongful restraint
339.legal_text: Whoever voluntarily obstructs any person so as to prevent that person from proceeding in any direction in which that person has a right to proceed.
339.nature:
Definition (Punished under 341)
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
339.practical_explanation: Stopping someone from going where they want to go.
339.example: Blocking someone's path on a sidewalk.

341.title: Punishment for wrongful restraint
341.legal_text: Whoever wrongfully restrains any person shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine, or with both.
341.punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 1 month, or fine, or both
341.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
341.example: Preventing a neighbor from leaving their house.

340.title: Wrongful confinement
340.legal_text: Whoever wrongfully restrains any person in such a manner as to prevent that person from proceedings beyond certain circumscribing limits.
340.nature:
Definition (Punished under 342)
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
340.practical_explanation: Locking someone in a room or space against their will.

342.title: Punishment for wrongful confinement
342.legal_text: Whoever wrongfully confines any person shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
342.punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both
342.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
342.example: Unlawful detention by a security guard.

351.title: Assault
351.legal_text: Whoever makes any gesture, or any preparation intending or knowing it to be likely that such gesture... will cause any person present to apprehend that he... is about to use criminal force.
351.nature:
Definition (Punished under 352)
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
351.practical_explanation: Threatening gesture making someone fear immediate violence.
351.example: Raising a fist as if to hit someone.

352.title: Punishment for assault or criminal force otherwise than on grave provocation
352.legal_text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person otherwise than on grave and sudden provocation...
352.punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine, or both
352.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate

353.title: Assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty
353.legal_text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person being a public servant in the execution of his duty...
353.punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both
353.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
353.practical_explanation: Pushing or attacking an official to stop them from working.
353.example: Shoving a police officer during a protest.

354C.title: Voyeurism
354C.legal_text: Any man who watches, or captures the image of a woman engaging in a private act in circumstances where she would usually have the expectation of not being observed.
354C.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable (1st offence), Non-bailable (2nd)
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
354C.practical_explanation: Peeping or recording women in private moments.
354C.example: Hidden camera in a changing room.

354D.title: Stalking
354D.legal_text: Any man who follows a woman and contacts, or attempts to contact such woman to foster personal interaction repeatedly despite a clear indication of disinterest; or monitors usage by a woman of the internet, email or any other form of electronic communication.
354D.punishment: First conviction: Up to 3 years; Second: Up to 5 years
354D.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable (1st offence), Non-bailable (2nd)
Non-compoundable
Triable by Any Magistrate
354D.practical_explanation: Following a woman or monitoring her online against her will.
354D.example: Repeatedly messaging a woman who has blocked you.

359.title: Kidnapping
359.legal_text: Kidnapping is of two kinds: kidnapping from India, and kidnapping from lawful guardianship.
359.nature:
Definition (Punished under 363)
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
359.practical_explanation: Taking a minor away from parents without consent.
359.example: Taking a child from school without parent's permission.

363.title: Punishment for kidnapping
363.legal_text: Whoever kidnaps any person from India or from lawful guardianship shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
363.punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine
363.nature:
Cognizable
Bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Magistrate of First Class

375.title: Rape
375.legal_text: A man is said to commit 'rape' who has sexual intercourse with a woman under circumstances falling under any of the seven descriptions (against her will, without consent, etc.).
375.nature:
Definition (Punished under 376)
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session

376.title: Punishment for rape
376.legal_text: Whoever commits rape shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment of not less than ten years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
376.nature:
Cognizable
Non-bailable
Non-compoundable
Triable by Court of Session
376.conclusion: One of the most severe punishments in IPC.

494.title: Marrying again during lifetime of husband or wife
494.legal_text: Whoever, having a husband or wife living, marries in any case in which such marriage is void by reason of its taking place during the life of such husband or wife.
494.punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine
494.nature:
Non-cognizable
Bailable
Compoundable (with permission)
Triable by Magistrate of First Class
494.practical_explanation: Bigamy; marrying someone else while already married.
494.example: Husband marrying a second wife without divorcing the first.
